title: Feature: add mapProperty function
body: Hey, I've been working with lodash quite intensely for a while now and first off I love it!! but - I always add my own mixin for this function that maps a property of an item. ps. I know its not a big change to the usage, but it comes very handy when working with chains Thanks! suggested function ``` javascript function mapProperty(item, property, fn){ return _.map(item[property], fn) } ``` usage before ``` javascript var newItem = _.map(item.property,myFunc) _(data.feeds).chain().mapProperty(transformFeed) ``` after ``` javascript var newItem = _.mapProperty(item, property,myFunc) _(data).chain().mapProperty('feeds', transformFeed) ```

title: No product method
body:
Ruby has a method called product (sometimes known as outer product), which takes all pairs generated from two arrays. It's hard to explain, here is a Ruby example.

`[1,2,3].product([4,5])     #=> [[1,4],[1,5],[2,4],[2,5],[3,4],[3,5]]`

I can do this for two arrays, for example (using _range(1) as a stand in):

`__flatten(_.map(_.range(10), function(x) { return _.map(_.range(10), function(y) { return [x,y] } ) } ));`

In general I would like two functions: product and productWith, which would mirror zip and zipWith.

I find these functions useful whenever I would normally use two nested loops.

I am happy to provide a neat implementation of these functions (I already have them privately), I wanted to check if they would be accepted, and also I haven't just missed them somewhere (or a shorter way of writing them).

title: isPlainObject throws "Member not found" on element in IE8
body:
Using IE8 (mine is a VM from modern.ie), go to lodash.com, open a console, then do:

``` js
_.isPlainObject(document.createElement('div'));
```

I get a "Member not found" error. `(document.createElement('div')).toString();` returns "[object]", not "[object Object]", so I'm not sure why isPlainObject is even getting past that. Sorry if I'm missing something obvious.

![screen shot 2015-05-27 at 3 17 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/166/7848770/afb8470a-0483-11e5-94c7-69feb79d7c07.png)
![screen shot 2015-05-27 at 3 17 28 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/166/7848773/b114a6b6-0483-11e5-8cb0-ba7e22cd0aef.png)

Currently I create my own `param` helper accord with this [answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/1714899). But it will be better if I can handy use it by lodash.

There's a one-liner for that: http://www.jsoneliners.com/function/is-scalar/

title: add tests for isIndex and set()
body:
for the case of an input string like "1string"
  currently these two tests fail, and they should not

See #1229

title: set() fails to set keys/value with certain inputs
body:
Take for example:

```
var hash = {};
_Lo.set(hash, ['a','1string'], 'myvalue');
```

I expect this to yield: `{ "a" : { "1string" : "myvalue" } }` but instead it yields: `{ "a" : [] }`

I narrowed the issue down to isIndex() returning true when "1string" is the input. I am filing a pull request which contains failing tests but will pass when this problem is fixed. Apologies I do not know javascript's weird edge cases well enough to quickly fix the problem; I'm hoping that someone else sees a simple solution.

title: Is there a functionality to flatten/deflatten an object?
body:
Hi there,

I have the following object/array of objects:
Object1: 

`````` json
{ id: 2,
    balance: 130,
    'Issue :  { 
         'id': 1,
         'currency': 'EUR'
   }
}```

Object2: 
```json
{ id: 2,
    balance: 130,
    'Issue.id': 1,
    'Issue.currency': 'EUR'
}
``````

Is there a way to 'deflatten' object1 into object2 and flatten object2 into object1?

Thanks

title: Minified version on NPM
body:
This was probably asked before but I couldn't find the bug related to this so I'm asking anyway, just in case. If this was already discussed somewhere, a _simple reply with a link to the proper topic_ would be fine by me.

With the growing number of people using NPM to retrieve their node modules as well as their front modules of which I am part of (I dislike bower and would like an NPM plugin to better handle front packages instead), I believe lodash needs a proper way to get files for the browser from NPM. Some examples might be the number of angular related stuff poping on NPM (including the official lib with its 144 178 downloads per month which is respectful for a latecomer in the available installation processes of this lib).

I don't claim to know how it should be done, maybe by publishing packages with a `front-` prefix containing the files you would get with bower… Another way would be to add a `browser/` folder with those in the existing packages. I'm sure there are other means to achieve this.

What are your thoughts on this?

Thanks a lot for your hard work until now (I LOVE lodash)!

title: Undocumented 2.4.1 -> 3.9.0 changes to _.mapValues with string arguments
body:
In lodash 3.9.0, _.mapValues converts string arguments passed in as the object parameter to character arrays. _.mapValues calls baseForOwn, which initiates a chain of calls down to createBaseFor which itself calls toObject() on the object parameter passed to _.mapValues(). toObject explicitly checks for string arguments and converts them into character arrays. (Sorry if this is overly verbose, I'm just documenting what I'm seeing).

In lodash 2.4.1, no such conversion happens. _.mapValues calls forOwn, which checks (on line 2097) if the argument passed in is of type string, and simply returns the string in that case.

I guess my question is, why was this change made? Also, as far as I can tell this change hasn't been documented anywhere.

Here are two jsbins demonstrating the change in behavior I'm talking about:
2.4.1 - http://jsbin.com/bafelarari/1/edit
3.9.0 - http://jsbin.com/derenasici/1/edit

title: findIndex and find do not seem to work sometimes
body:
Sometimes when working with `_.findIndex()` and `_.find()` the functions return `-1` or `undefined` unexpectedly. An example of an `.html` file that generates the unexpected behavior for me can be found here: http://pastebin.com/2QQ5DFVJ

The version of lodash I am using is 3.9.0, it does not seem to work with both the modern build and the compatibility build.

I tested this in both Chromium 41.0.2272.76 and Firefox 38.0, both of which show unexpected behavior.

title: Be able to control depth of _.isEqual?
body:
I'm wondering if it's worth to control how deep of a comparison `_.isEqual` performs.

API could be like: `_.isEqual(value, other, [customizer], [thisArg], [depth])`.

So, something like `_.isEqual(value, other, 1)` would do shallow comparison.

title: Partial arguments for method() aren't documented
body:
Unless I'm missing it, I couldn't find any documentation for [method()](https://lodash.com/docs#method) about partially-applying arguments. It let's you do this, and this is a huge win. At least for me anyway - it's not very often that I map method calls _without_ arguments.

Even a simple example, I think, would suffice for most folks:

``` javascript
_.map('abc', _.method('replace', 'a', 'b')).join('');
```

title: _.sortBy not working with non-ASCII characters
body:
I 've noticed, that _.sortBy function returns wrong result, if strings include non-ascii characters.
Sample:

``` js
var items = [{ id: 1, name: 'étest' }, { id: 2, name: 'etest' }, { id: 3, name: 'ùtest' }, { id: 4, name: 'atest' }, { id: 5, name: 'utest' }];
var wrongSortedArr = _.sortBy(items, 'name');
```

Result: `atest, etest, utest, étest, ùtest`.

I 've made custom solution helping with javascript array.sort and localeCompare function.
The result should be: `atest, etest, étest, utest, ùtest`

Is there any option in lodash for sorting objects in array including non-ascii characters?

title: _.uniq iteratee as comparator
What's the official way to check if the object is wrapped in _(..)?
body:
I'm trying to allow passing in an array or a lodash wrapped instance into a function. If a lodash instance is passed in - I need to unwrap it (`.value()`), but how do I check if it really is a lodash instance?

I'm looking for something like `_.isLodash`.. or alternatively, I wouldn't care about it if the following were true, but I'm not sure that's a legit wish :)

``` js
var wrapped = _([ 1, 2, 3 ]);

console.log(_.toArray(wrapped)); // [ 1, 2, 3 ] 
```

I'm somewhat reluctant to call `.value()` just because it's a function that exists on an object...

title: NPM Error - bufferClone.js

title: Pull with predicate, without mutating the original
_.get returns undefined when nested value is NULL
body:
This could be a result of #1136:

`_.get({ a: { b: null }}, 'a.b')` returns `undefined` instead of `NULL`.

In the example `a.b` is a valid path but instead of returning its value, `undefined` is returned even though the property exists.

title: collection being added in map function in 3.8.0?
body:
http://jsfiddle.net/ilazarte/j14f26rd/1/

Maybe I'm missing something, but shouldn't the resulting collection produce what expected produces?

title: Undocumented v2 -> v3 breaking changes with chaining
body:
The [v3 release notes](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/3.0.0) Breaking Changes section is pretty minimal; it only lists "dropped support for Underscore/Backbone build", which gives the impression that there should not be breaking changes if you're not using the Underscore/Backbone build, while in reality there are some breaking changes.

The main breaking change I've seen is that chains must now end with `.value()` or equivalent in order to execute.  Previously, chains wouldn't return a value if they didn't end with `.value()`, but could be used for side-effects.  For example:

```
_([1,3,5]).each((x) => console.log(x));
```

In lodash v2.x, this will log each item of the array, while in v3.x this will do nothing.

It'd be nice if this sort of change were documented somewhere, preferably the v3 release notes, but as far as I can see, it isn't.

title: Exception thrown when `flow` and `partial` are used together
body:
If `flow` and `partial` are included on their own (e.g. `require( "lodash/function/flow" )`) and are used together, an exception is thrown.

I have created [a repository](https://github.com/bjohn465/lodash-flow-bug/) with [code that demonstrates the issue](https://github.com/bjohn465/lodash-flow-bug/blob/22230b0baa3ce0a42ce51c1843a723c8a6375a37/index.js).

The exception thrown when running this test code is:

```
TypeError: undefined is not a function
    at C:\code\lodash-flow-bug\node_modules\lodash\internal\createFlow.js:51:90
```

When lodash is included with `require( "lodash" )` and `_.partial` is used with `_.flow`, an exception is not thrown.

title: Improve remove performance
body:
When profiling our application, I saw a significant amount of time spent in our calls to _.remove().
When looking at the current code, I saw that it builds an array of indices to remove from the source array, and then uses basePullAt to remove the elements.

basePullAt for some reason allows to use anything as index, which is why it uses parseFloat().

So I decided to inline a specialized version which knows that the passed arguments are valid integer indices.

PS: I filled out the CLA (submitted a CLA on 2015-05-15 12:50:41)
PPS: I could not figure out if I need to change the es branch as well.

title: _.find function's .matchesProperty shorthand producing unusual behavior when undefined is passed as the value
body:
The `_.find` function is supposed to return undefined if an element is not matched.

However, using the `_.matchesProperty` callback shorthand produces unusual behavior when undefined is passed as the value.

If `_.matchesProperty` is used directly, the behavior is as expected.

``` JavaScript
var family = [{id: 0, name: 'Nathan'}, {id: 1, name: 'Julianne'}, {id: 2, name: 'Alex'}];
_.find(family, _.matchesProperty('id', 2)); //=> Object {id: 2, name: "Alex"}
_.find(family, _.matchesProperty('id', undefined)); //=> undefined
```

However, using the shorthand produces the wrong result.

``` JavaScript
_.find(family, 'id', 2); //=> Object {id: 2, name: "Alex"}
_.find(family, 'id', undefined); //=> Object {id: 1, name: "Julianne"}
```

My preliminary look seems to indicate that the issue comes from the final ternary return statement in `baseCallback(func, thisArg, argCount)`.

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3.8.0/lodash.js#L1733-L1735

If the ternary is removed and `return baseMatchesProperty(func, thisArg);` is allowed for cases where `thisArg` is `undefined`, it seems that the issue goes away and all the test cases still pass.

title: _.includesAll and _.includesSome?
body:
I'd like to be able to do things like this:

``` javascript
_.includesAll([1, 2, 3, 4], 2, 3) // => true, 2 and 3 are all in the array
_.includesAll([1, 2, 3, 4], 1, 4, 5) // => false, 5 is not in the array

_.includesSome([1, 2, 3, 4], 1, 4, 5) // => true, some of the values (1, 4) are in the array
_.includesSome([1, 2, 3, 4], 2, 3) // => true, ditto^
_.includesSome([1, 2, 3, 4], 5) // => false, none of the values (5) is in the array
```

It may be that I'm unaware of some part of the API that already does this (apologies, if so). I _am_ aware that I could use composition to do this, but I'm thinking that it might be worth implementing these methods as part of Lodash itself (I'd be willing to do so; I was initially surprised that `_.includes` doesn't support something along these lines). Thoughts? Is the reply just the same as in #750 and #576 (i.e., sorry, just use composition)?

Thanks.

title: Provide guidance on how to build the documentation
body:
When I clone github.com/lodash/lodash, I expect to find a `docs/index.html` file or similar which you can open and the docs are there, or a README which explains how to build and view the docs locally. A good example of this is `three.js` which has an index.html, which you can open and all of the links work even when you don't have an internet connection.

There is a doc/README.md, which looks like it's meant to be parsed by a machine more than a person. I also checked the CONTRIBUTING.md file and the main README file; I didn't see any information on how to build the docs.

title: findWhere should fail early
body:
I've been working to upgrade my companies lodash from 2.4.1 to 3.x. One of the things that has frustrated the upgrade is findWhere used to be an alias of find and now unlike find only takes objects. 

But findWhere still will gladly accept a function. It hands it to baseMatches sees that it doesn't have length and returns a constant true. So places in our code base that were calling findWhere with a function are always getting back the first element of the collection. 

I think findWhere should error out in the event of using it like find. Having it act like it still accepts a function and even returning s single element. It pushes the failure down stream making it harder to pinpoint what went wrong.

title: _.each failing in ie8 when adding a comma to an object
difference not working for short arrays
body:
Using lodash version 3.8.0 and 3.1.0 the following code:

``` js
_.difference([1], [1,2]);
```

returns an empty array.

``` js
_.difference([1,3], [2]);
```

returns `[1,3]` but skips 2
and

``` js
_.difference([1,3], [2,4]);
```

also returns `[1,3]`

title: _.fill with object
_.debounce/_.throttle return values
[Feature] Shuffle with seed
body:
Hello, 

Added a seed parameter to shuffle.
It shuffle the collection based on a string or number. Better known as "seed". 
This feature is very useful for many tasks like security scripts, gaming developing, custom encryption, image scramble, etc.
### Usage

``` js
_.shuffle([1, 2, 3, 4], 'dog');
// => [ 3, 4, 1, 2 ]

_.shuffle([1, 2, 3, 4], 'dog'); 
// => [ 3, 4, 1, 2 ] // same
```
- Create 4 tests for shuffle with seed on test.js
- Add to docs.

Hope you guys like it.

title: intersection behaviour unintuitive and documentation unclear
body:
I have read #1147 and #1189 regarding the changed behaviour of `intersection()` when applied to a single list.

I am not sure it is sensible behaviour to assume that the caller wanted an empty list silently inserted for comparison.

The documentation does not make this clear: [_"Creates an array of unique values in all provided arrays..."_](https://lodash.com/docs#intersection) certainly the inserted list should not be considered a provided array, as it was not provided. From reading the documentation I would expect the returned array to be equal to a `uniq()` of the single input array.

I understand the argument that from a semantic point of view the word intersection implies `2..n` cardinality, however if this is the case it would be more useful to throw an error than assume that the caller desired an empty array returned - which is almost certainly not what the caller expected.

body:
``` js _.templateSettings.escape = /{{([\s\S]+?)}}/g _.templateSettings.interpolate = /{{{([\s\S]+?)}}}/g _.template('foo {{obj}} bar')('

hi

') // => "foo <h1>hi</h1> bar" _.template('foo {{{obj}}} bar')('

hi

') // => SyntaxError: Unexpected token ) ``` http://jsbin.com/hupafo/1/edit?js,console

title: isNative issues
body:
1. [`lodash` uses `Object#toString` as template for `isNative`](https://gist.github.com/jdalton/5e34d890105aca44399f#file-isnative-js-L32-L43) assuming that is native function. But ES6 changed [`Object#toString` logic for support `Symbol.toStringTag`](http://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.prototype.tostring). [`core-js`](https://github.com/zloirock/core-js) from first versions [adds polyfill for this logic](https://goo.gl/Dh1LwI) and replaces `Object#toString`. `_.isNative` works wrong for **all** native functions with `core-js` / `babel` and some other libraries:

``` js
require('core-js');
require('lodash').isNative(Object);   // => false
require('lodash').isNative(Function); // => false
require('lodash').isNative(isNaN);    // => false
```

I will add fallback for `lodash` in next version `core-js`, but `lodash` should use native function whose logic shouldn't be changed in ES6+.
2. `lodash` [uses `isNative` for detect `Set`, `WeakMap`,  some object methods](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L740-L754) - but why? In most polyfills, **native** methods wrapped for correct work by latest spec and, with this check, will not work with `lodash`. Related #981. Better use correct feature detection.

title: Helper method to return a function that calls the first argument with the current context
Addition of _.next, _.previous and _.placeInRange
body:
While working on a recent project, I found the addition of the following three simple methods could prove both helpful to a large number of lodash users, and that they feel inline with the existing methods available:

`_.next` - Given an array and one of it's elements, return the next element.
`_.previous` - Similar, but returning the previous element of the array.

`_.placeInRange` - Ensures that a value falls within a range, returning the start or end value if the value provided happens to exceed or fall short of the range.

Have submitted this as a pull request, but it's more an example implementation to trigger discussion. My most recent use case is building a dynamic Grid composed of resizable columns, where I'm wanting to enforce min/max resize limits, and easily obtain the preceding or subsequent column.

(random note: have been inspired to contribute towards lodash after listening to the awesome JSJabber episode with John-David Dalton - love the unrelenting push for improvement).

title: Is it possible or any plan to make lodash some compiling language?
body:
Hi,

lodash is really a perfect handy utilities collection for javascript, thank you guys for providing it. But in a real project, not all functions are needed instead usually a small part. So the code size will be a problem for a small or medium browser side application. If it could pre-process project source code and just import those used functions, I believe the code size will significantly reduced. Say that it's just like Babel which translates ES6 features to ES5.

Do you think it's a possible direction? Thanks!

Best,
Nate Wang

title: TypeError: Class constructors cannot be invoked without 'new'
body:
Using ES6 classes, the native bound function works.

``` javascript
class A {}
var ABound = A.bind(null, 1, 2, 3)
var a = new ABound()
```

Where as using lodash bind function, it doesn't work.

``` javascript
class A {}
var ABound = _.bind(A, null, 1, 2, 3)
var a = new ABound()
```

Following exception is thrown 

``` stack
TypeError: Class constructors cannot be invoked without 'new'
    at new A (repl:1:23)
    at /Users/tusharmathur/Documents/Projects/ioc/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3230:27
    at new wrapper (/Users/tusharmathur/Documents/Projects/ioc/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3653:19)
    at repl:1:5
```

Looking at the code it seems obvious why, but is it the expected behaviour?

title: a bug of  _.memoize
Permutations
body:
I think an useful addition to the library would be a "permutations" function that given n arrays, returns an array of all the possible permutations of their values. Eg:

``` js
_.permutations([0, 1], ['a', 'b']) => [[0, 'a'], [0, 'b'], [1, 'a'], [1, 'b']];
```

title: Feature proposition: "namespace"
body:
Basically speaking:

``` javascript
/**
 * Set or get a possibly nested property of the root object.
 * Fail nicely if the path breaks at some point.
 *
 * @param {object} root    - object to operate on
 * @param {string} path    - dot-separated path identifing the requested resource
 * @param {*}      [value] - if present, the value will be set at the give path
 */
function namespace(root, path, value) {
  // ...
}
```

The name of the function may not be the most fortunate choice though. Example usage:

``` javascript
namespace({}, 'a.b.c', 1); // -> { a: { b: { c: 1 } } }
namespace({}, 'a.b.c');    // undefined instead of throwing error
```

From my experience this is extremely useful for parsing configuration objects, which may contain nested options.

title: a bug of `intersection`
body:
``` javascript
_.intersection([1, 3, 4]);
```
- expected: [1, 3, 4]
- got: []

This bug is in lodash@3.8.0 and lodash@3.5.0 or other versions(?) on **NodeJS**.
But it works as expected in lodash@3.6.0 on **Browser**.

title: sortByOrder can sort properties with null values
body:
Without this fix, sortByOrder will just silently leave collections will null sorted properties partially sorted. 

See http://codepen.io/ignu/pen/RPPOwO?editors=001

title: Min/Max decimal error, not giving correct
Support ES6 Map/Set/WeakMap/WeakSet in _.toArray
body:
There is no builtin, widely supported way to create an array from ES6 [Map](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Map) and [Set](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Set) entities (values or keys). Eventually [Array.from](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/from) will solve this problem, but it is not as widely supported as the data structures.

It would be great if `_.toArray` were able to fill this gap – not just for `Map` and `Set`, but for any [iterator](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Iteration_protocols). Both `Set` and `Map` have `.forEach` properties, and `Map` also has `values` and `keys`. All of these conform to the iterator protocol.

:beers:

title: call-n-times
body:
May [call-n-times](https://github.com/PolicyStat/call-n-times) be a suitable addition to lodash?
It was [mentioned in the popular DailyJS](http://dailyjs.com/2015/01/13/testharness-call-modern/).

Also, I welcome any comments on it.

title: Add `_.pascalCase`
#with
_.flattenObject
body:
``` coffee
recurse = (v, k) -> if _.isObject(v) then collapse(v) else [[k, v]]
collapse = (json) -> _.flatten(_.map(json, recurse))
flattenObject = _.zipObject collapse

// or,
flattenObject = (object, accumulator = {}) ->

    _.mapValues object, (value, key) ->

      if _.isPlainObject value
      then _.flattenObject value, accumulator
      else accumulator[key] = value

    accumulator

flattenObject { a: { b: 1 }, c: 2 }
# => { b: 1, c: 2 }
```

title: Changelog header is confusing
body:
I check the [Changelog](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Changelog) semi-frequently and maybe I'm particularly dim, but this message that gets put inside the top of every new release and retroactively removed from the previous releases always throws me for several loops:

> See the [release notes](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases) for overviews & highlights of this & other releases.
> Use [lodash-migrate](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash-migrate) to help migrate older lodash code to the latest release.

The release notes link doesn't lead to any useful description about the changes. The changelog page that I'm already on is much more useful! On many occasions I've seen a new lodash version, gone to the changelog page, followed the link to the release notes as I assumed it was trying to tell me the release notes is where the canonical information on releases is, and then gotten lost trying to navigate through github to find the notes on the new release.

The lodash-migrate link is strange because it makes me worry about backwards incompatibilities and wonder why lodash has suddenly stopped following semver, but it doesn't look like the 3.8.0 release actually adds any backwards incompatibilities. I think to myself that every release probably mentions lodash-migrate, but then I see that the previous couple releases don't mention it, so then I double check to make sure that the latest release really doesn't add any backwards incompatibilities. I start to wonder whether or not my memory of seeing that note on the 3.7.0 release in the past is right and if I'm being gaslighted.

If that header was above the releases list in the changelog rather than always being made part of the latest release, it would be a little better I think.

title: Will baseSortBy() always use the native Array.prototype.sort()?
body:
Some people consider the use of [code point sorting](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort) in `Array.prototype.sort()` to be one of the “bad parts” of JavaScript:

``` javascript
['12', '1', '2'].sort() // => ['1', '12', '2']
```

I’m actually counting on this behavior. I’d like to use lodash’s `_.sortBy()` in a chain of other transformations. It looks like lodash uses `Array.prototype.sort()` [under the hood](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/b75041173c9aa35343fb4be44d7a28a8acae03f3/lodash.js#L2671). Can you, the core contributors, think of a reason you might ever to swap out the native sort method for your own? If so, is there a way to use something like `_.thru()` to pipe a lodash-ified array through `Array.prototype.sort()`?

title: _.isBlank(str)
body:
Hi!  Thanks for helping me put bread on my family's table!

Anyhow, I found the isBlank() semantics pretty useful back in the day when doing Java coding with Commons Lang.  I looked for it today in lodash and when I found it wasn't there I rolled my own with `_.isString()` and `_.trim()` and `length > 0`.

Here's the function I'm thinking about:

https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.html#isBlank%28java.lang.CharSequence%29

Perhaps our take on `_.isBlank()` could fallback to `_.isEmpty()` semantics for non-String types.

title: (doc/changelog) _.findWhere (alias -> self contained) migration was not documented
body:
Until **3.0** (I believe) `_.findWhere` was an alias to `_.find`, and thus accepted all 3 kinds of predicate that the later accepts: `(Function|Object|string)`. Recently, it became a self contained method, and only works in the `Object` predicate option.
This split/migration was **not** mentioned on the changelog and breaks any code calling `_.findWhere` with a predicate other than `Object`.

Although I'm kinda late to the party, adding a mention to it now might still help some people who are waiting for whatever reason to migrate to 3.x.

As a matter of curiousity, what's the motivation for spliting generalist methods and its aliases into specialist ones, other than eventual performance optimizations and less edge case intersections?

title: Thoughts on a throttling function which leverages requestAnimationFrame?
_.flow breaks when upgrading from 3.5.0 to 3.6.0/3.7.0
body:
The following code executed well in lodash v.3.5.0,
but breaks in 3.6.0 and 3.7.0 (see below).

``` javascript
var _ = require('lodash');

console.log(
    _([ { id: 'a' }
      , { id: 'b' }
      ])
        .filter(_.flow(
            _.partial(_.result, _, 'id')
          , _.partial(_.isEqual, _, 'a')
        ))
        .value()
);
```

In v.3.5.0, this would yield `[ { id: 'a' } ]`

However, in 3.6.0 and 3.7.0, it throws:

```
/[...]/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3267
            wrapper = wrapper[getFuncName(data[0])].apply(wrapper, data[3]);
                                                   ^
TypeError: Cannot read property 'apply' of undefined
    at Function.<anonymous> (/[...]/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3267:52)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/[...]/proof.js:7:19)
    at Module._compile (module.js:460:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:478:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:355:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:310:12)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:501:10)
    at startup (node.js:129:16)
    at node.js:814:3
```

title: _.intersection does not work on DOMTokenList
body:
I was trying to get an element's classList to see if it had one of a particular list of classes:

``` javascript
var classes = e.currentTarget.classList;
var findClasses = ["foo-1", "foo-2", "bar-7", "foobar-8"];
```

However, while `findClasses` is definitely an instance of `Array`, `classes` is an instance of `DOMTokenList`. This object is iterable, but it is not strictly an instance of `Array`. So I get this:

``` javascript
> classes
["foo-1", "col", "activated"]
> _.intersection(classes, findClasses)
[]
> _.intersection(["foo-1", "col", "activated"], findClasses)
["foo-1"]
```

In [lodash.src.js:5297](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.src.js#L5297), the variable `classes` will fail the `isArray()` test, since `Array.isArray(classes)` is `false`. Any other function that depends on `isArray()` will also likely exhibit the same behavior, though I didn't try to find any others.

The same code works in Underscore, since Underscore doesn't seem to use `Array.isArray` as a prerequisite for iterating through the objects.

title: Variable is assigned to itself
body:
The code inspection in WebStorm complains:

file .../lodash/lodash.js
Variable is assigned to itself at line 752

The line in question reads

``` js
var ...,
    preventExtensions = isNative(Object.preventExtensions = Object.preventExtensions) && preventExtensions, ...
```

I'm a relative newcomer to JavaScript and don't pretend to understand everything that's going on here, but it does look like a potential bug, particularly when compared to the initializer for `getOwnPropertySymbols` three lines earlier.

title: Add `_.isAll` and `_.isAny`

- Added associated tests.

title: deep path support for zipObject
body:
The deep path support in 3.7.0 is exciting! After updating, my first use case was for zipping an array into an object, where some of the property names use bracket/subscript notation. (More specifically, my use case is a quick one-liner to parse a query string into an object.)

``` js
_([
  [ "a[b]", 1 ],
  [ "a.c", 2 ]
]).object().value() //=>  { a: { b:1, c:2 } }
```

There are a couple of questions as to how this would be handled for `zipObject`.

Clearly when zipping objects, the deep path parsing would need to be optional. But we also have a number of different sub-features:
1. handling subscript notation with string key: `"a[b]"`
2. handling dot notation: `"a.b"`
3. handling empty subscript (to result in an array property): `"b[]"`
4. handling explicit numerical subscript: (result in array? or object? object with string keys or numbers?): `"b[0]"`

And there's the interplay with `_.pairs` to think about, as well.

Fixes #1149

title: Lots of unused files
body:
It looks like lodash includes lots of files in the npm distro that don't appear to be used.

``` sh
$ npm install lodash
lodash@3.7.0 node_modules/lodash
$ find node_modules/lodash | wc -l
     413
```

It doesn't look like these files are required by `index.js` so I was just wondering why they are distributed?

title: _.isNumeric
body:
Hi all –

I know that `isFinite` and `isNumber` and `isNaN` have been discussed ad nauseum, but I think they leave a big gap in functionality.

Given that JS is not typed, when working with third-party data, it's often important to check whether something is "numeric".

This would function as follows:

``` js
_.isNumeric() // => false
_.isNumeric(undefined) // => false
_.isNumeric(null) // => false
_.isNumeric(new Number()) // => false
_.isNumeric(Infinity) // => false
_.isNumeric(15.5) // => true
_.isNumeric("15.5") // => true
```

I find that I'm often cobbling together some combination of functions to achieve this. I believe that it could be solved with something like the following.

``` js
function isNumeric(x) {
  return !(isNaN(x)) && (typeof x !== "object") &&
    (x != Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY) && (x != Number.NEGATIVE_INFINITY);
}
```

Cheers!

(Edited code to correct inequality)

`lodash@3.7.0`:

Possibly caused by the fix for #1085?

title: _.get() key with quotes
body:
Is it possible?

``` javascript
var object = { 'a': [{ 'foo "bar"': { 'c': 3 } }] };

_.get(object, 'a[0]["foo \"bar\""].c'); // undefined (but should be 3)
```

title: Pluck should return same collection type and maintain keys
body:
Right now, `pluck` always returns an array, regardless of the type of collection you give it.  A use case I'm running into is using `indexBy` and `pluck` to adapt an array of objects.  I'd expect to be able to do this with:

```
_.pluck(_.indexBy(data, 'id'), 'value');
```

To turn this:

```
[
    {
        "id": 1,
        "value": "foo"
    }
]
```

Into this:

```
{
    "1": "foo"
}
```

But the actual result is an array with they keys lost.

```
[
    "foo"
]
```

I'd be happy to submit a pull-request to fix this, but I want to know if this is a desired behavior before I go to the trouble.  Is there a particular reason that it _should_ always return an array?

title: adding support to _.has for multiply paths
body: so… you'll be able to make this sort of testing: `_.has(obj, 'a', 'b')` which will be shortcut for this `_.has(obj, 'a') && _.has(obj, 'b')`
